description: ERECTION OF A TWO STOREY EXTENSION TO FORM A THREE BEDROOM DWELLING HOUSE.
decision_conditions: Reason : 1 - The proposal would, by virtue of its height, scale and siting constitute an unneighbourly form of development that would be visually intrusive, oppressive and result in an increased sense of enclosure to the outdoor amenities of the occupiers of 19B Russell Road, contrary to policies DM D2 and DM D3 of the Sites and Policies Plan (2014).

Reason : 2 - The proposal would, by virtue of its design, height, scale and siting result in a visually intrusive form of development to the local area and streetscene, out of keeping with the host bungalow building, contrary to policies DM D2 and DM D3 of the Sites and Policies Plan (2014) and Policy CS 14 of the Core Strategy (2011).

Reason : 2 - The proposal would, by virtue of its design, height, scale and siting result in a visually intrusive form of development to the local area and streetscene, out of keeping with the host bungalow building, contrary to policies DM D2 and DM D3 of the Sites and Policies Plan (2014) and Policy CS 14 of the Core Strategy (2011).

Reason : 3 - INFORMATIVE
Note to Applicant
In accordance with paragraph 38 of the NPPF, The London Borough of Merton  (LBM) takes a positive and proactive approach to development proposals focused on solutions. LBM works with applicants/agents in a positive and proactive manner by:
"	Offering a pre-application advice and duty desk service. 
"	Where possible, suggesting solutions to secure a successful outcome.
"	As appropriate, updating applicants/agents of any issues that may arise in the processing of their application.
In this instance:
"	The application was not considered to comply with the provisions of the Development Plan and NPPF as submitted, and would have required substantial changes such that a new application would be required. 
"	The applicant/agent was informed of any issues arising during consideration of the application and how these could potentially be overcome but sufficient information was not forthcoming. Officers reviewed amended plans for a reduced scale proposal, however, these were not formally put forward for determination by the applicant under the current planning applciation.  
"	The application was considered to be fundamentally contrary to the provisions of the Development Plan and the NPPF, and there were not considered to be any solutions to resolve this conflict. 
"	The applicant is advised to seek pre-application advice on any resubmission.
